page.title: 17ORNITHOLOGY IN BERE FERRERS.
page.content: Our group first visited Bere Ferrers in December, long before we knew it was to be our Domesday Block. Members of the Young Ornithologists Club met one of the leaders of the Plymouth group so that he and his wife could show us a flock of that lovely winter visitor-the Avocet. We watched those graceful waders with their delicately curved bills scooping the mud flats for crustaceans. Bere Ferrers is a staging post for passing migrants and a local breeding ground for populations of Mute Swan, Shell Duck and Mallard. On our summer visit we saw Swallows House Martins and Swifts catching insects in their swooping flight near the river. We also saw a Whimbrel feeding. Rare visitors seen recently are the Night Heron and the Spotted Sandpiper.
